title: Why I hate RPG's
content:
To me, most role-playing games suck. Period.

Why?

Because when I play a game, I'm playing it for three specific purposes:

One: A good story. I want to get lost in the universe of the game, I want to like the character and vicariously feel a part of his battles. RPG's have the same basic storyline, but with different faces: "I'm a poor boy. I have to save a princess. I didn't know I had magical powers. Yay, let's go fight some bosses. Game over."

Two: Controls. I hate playing the same game over again. That's why RPG's suck. They practically have the same controls, and power ups. I kill some guys, I get stronger. Then, I go fight more guys to get stronger. Then, I go fight more guys to get stronger. It's like being an automaton.

C: The scenery. Games need to look asthetically pleasing. They just need to. You should be able to have different terrians, , and wildlife for each place you go to. You are about to say, "Well, RPG ARE FULL OF THAT!" No, they're not. They all have: a water world, a forest world, a desert world, a mountain world, a castle world, and a fire world. That's a bare minimum. I can't even care about the scenery after it's felt like I've been fighting copycats in a the previous RPG I played.

BONUS: Versatility. I like using various weapons, or atleast having various powers that I collect along the way. RPG's kind of do this, but after the headache of battling the same fuclers a thousand times in a row, it hardly seems a fair trade.

With that said, there are a fwe RPG's that I love, just for being RPG's that are, imo, original.

Lord of the Rings: Two Towers for GBA.
Spike McFang for SNES.
Legend of Zelda (all)~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

[quote]Quote:[hr]LordofGlobox:

RPG's have the same basic storyline, but with different faces: "I'm a poor boy. I have to save a princess. I didn't know I had magical powers. Yay, let's go fight some bosses. Game over."[hr][/quote]
As compared to, say, Half-Life ("Oh, I'm a humdrum scientist. I didn't know aliens would invade. Yay, let's go fight the boss. Game over.") or Sonic ("Oh, I'm a hedgehog with attitude. I didn't know the evil doctor would kidnap my friends and turn them into robots. Yay, let's go kick his butt. Game over.") or even Asteroids ("Oh, I'm a little spaceship existing in space for no real reason. I didn't expect all these hunks of rock to appear. Yay, let's shoot them all. Game over."

If you reduce any story as heavily as you've chosen to, it's gonna seem pointless. Reductive analysis tends to obfuscate the real development.

[quote]Quote:[hr]LordofGlobox:
Two: Controls. I hate playing the same game over again. That's why RPG's suck. They practically have the same controls, and power ups. I kill some guys, I get stronger. Then, I go fight more guys to get stronger. Then, I go fight more guys to get stronger. It's like being an automaton.[hr][/quote]
Again, compared to the same games: Half-Life (kill monsters, get better weapon. Kill more monsters, get better weapons.) Sonic (Run fast to get items which help you run faster) or Asteroids (Shoot rocks to make more rocks appear which you also shoot) ... See where this is going?

[quote]Quote:[hr]LordofGlobox:
C: The scenery. Games need to look asthetically pleasing. They just need to. You should be able to have different terrians, , and wildlife for each place you go to. You are about to say, "Well, RPG ARE FULL OF THAT!" No, they're not. They all have: a water world, a forest world, a desert world, a mountain world, a castle world, and a fire world. That's a bare minimum. I can't even care about the scenery after it's felt like I've been fighting copycats in a the previous RPG I played.[hr][/quote]
Leaving the fact that you counted "1, 2, C" aside, Let's check out Half-Life for a moment. If you're not in the discarded remnants of the Black Mesa facility, you're in the Xeno world. That's about it. Sonic the Hedgehog has the Water world, Forest world, Fire world, etc--those are staples of varied environment and have nothing to do with RPGs specifically. Asteroids changed colors occasionally, I guess...

[quote]Quote:[hr]LordofGlobox:
And what other genres, becides shitty sports games, make the same game over again and dare to call it a different one?[hr][/quote]
Unreal Tournament's yearly installments; Metroid Prime is working on its third title; Mario Party's up to 7 or 8; We're all but guaranteed to see another Grand Theft Auto game; Metal Gear Solid has been spewing philosophy and way too many cutscenes down our throats for an upcoming 4th installment; Commander Keen had two damn-near-identical trilogies; Leisure Suit Larry followed the same guy for 7 or 8 games; Tetris has been re-made and re-marketted for years; Street Fighter 2 went through Championship Edition, Turbo, and a few other spin-offs; you already discounted sports games, but I COULD GO ON.

[quote]Quote:[hr]LordofGlobox:
I mean, give me a break. Tales of Symphonia is the only 'original' RPG --and it sucked. There's just nothing to do with RPG that hasn't already been done. Playing one RPG is just like playing the previous one and the next one --only with a modified story and graphics.[hr][/quote]
I felt that Tales was horribly derivative and uninspired, personally. But while we're talking about previous ones with new stories and graphics, mind explaining to me the difference between Doom, Quake, and Eradicator? How about Mario, Prehistorik Man, Jelly Boy, Rex Ronin, Awesome Possum, Aero-the-Acrobat, Bubsy the Bobcat, Crash Bandicoot, and Whirlo? How about Castlevania and Metroid? F-Zero and Wipeout? Mario Kart and Crash Team Racing? Sonic Shuffle, Fusion Frenzy, and Mario Party? Smash Bros. and Power Stone? Street Fighter 2 and Mortal Kombat? ... Commander Keen and Cosmo?

[quote]Quote:[hr]Still LordofGlobox:
And platformers are hardly retarded. Rayman, Megaman, Zelda, Halo, and others atleast were original or added some new form of game play other than "Press A, press A, press A, press B, press A, press C" ... Oh I beat the game![hr][/quote]
My mistake, you're absolutely right--I have to HOLD LEFT OR RIGHT while pressing "A, A, A, B, A, C" in order to win. Heaven forbid.

...

I can't believe you're so short-sighted as to pidgeonhole an entire genre because you haven't found a game that suits your tastes. The same oblivious arrogance can be said about anything--and I mean ANYTHING. Clothing, hair, food, music, entertainment, operating systems, cars, people, whatever.

Don't give up on the poor little RPG just yet. I can agree with you that there is an awful lot of crap out there these days--but there's always been an awful lot of crap in the gaming world. Back in the early 90's it was Platform games and 2d Fighters. In the mid-to-late 90's it was First Person Shooters and Multi-CD RPGs. Now that we're in the early 00's it's mostly about World War II and Cut Scenes that are WAY TOO LONG. Give it another 5 years... we'll move on to something new.

This wasn't meant to be a personal attack on you, LordofGlobox, but your arguments completely failed to convince me that you've played enough RPGs to pan the genre as a whole the way you did.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/posted-pics/XkyRauhKeenLogo.png[/img]

title: Hmm.
content:
I suppose it's a question of who wants what out of the game.

In a racing game, people will run the same oval-shaped track day and night in order to shave those last few hundredths of a second off of their lap time.
In an FPS, people will run the same multiplayer map day and night in order to perfect their headshot talents and sniping skills, so that in their clan matches they can be ranked #1.
In an MMORPG, people will camp the same monster day and night in order to get their ideal gear, which gives them bragging rights and makes their next challenge to the games instances that much easier.
In a traditional RPG, people will grind the same monsters day and night in order to hit the fabled "level 99" limit, which is a bragging point and makes the rest of the game easier.
In a platform game, people will run the same first few levels day and night in order to memorize enemy locations and perfect techniques for speedruns and showing off.

*shrugs* What do you look for, in any game, to satisfy you?

Some RPGs will create random dungeons for you, so that you're not grinding the same LOCATIONS over and over again (particularly those by Nippon Ichi, such as Disgaea, Phantom Brave, Makai Kingdrom)
Some RPGs are more action-oriented, and give you more control over your main character during combat, which gives the game a segmented, action-y feel. (Star Ocean, Tales of Symphonia/Legendia/etc.)
Some RPGs are extraordinarily tactical, asking the player to consider each individual's actions on a deeper level (Front Mission, Super Robot Wars, Final Fantasy Tactics, La Pucelle Tactics, etc.)
Some RPGs are more teamwork-based, and you can play them with friends (Secret of Mana, Final Fantasy Crystal Chronicles, Legend of Zelda: Four Swords Adventure)
Some RPGs are focussed hardcore around their plot, so that the gameplay becomes secondary (or tertiary) to viewing the cinematic cutscenes (Xenosaga)...
Lastly (in my mind), some RPGs are "classics," demonstrating the pinnacle of gameplay for the era they were released in (Chrono Trigger, Fallout 2, Knights of the Old Republic).

"RPG" is about as descriptive as "Rock," as far as genres go, these days...

content:
My blood is about to boil!!
When you say "I hate all RPGs", you obviously mean "I hate all jRPGs". Then I would agree totally with you. I hate every single jRPG ever made, without exceptions. Final Fantasy my ass!

But you CAN'T say you hate all RPGs when you OBVIOUSLY haven't played Fallout AND Fallout 2 AND Planescape Torment. How the HELL can you say they all have the same gameplay, same environment, same story. Fallout, for example, can have around 3 different endings to EACH of the towns you visit and there are about 10 of them. You can even finish the game without killing a single monster in the game! Or you can become a grinding machine and slaughter everyone in your way with your good old minigun or, just as effectively, your bare hands. Every person you meet in the game is a personality. When you talk with them, the things you say/ask/answer to them actually has EFFECT on the things that happen in the game world. ALL your actions have effect on how people react on you. Almost every quest in the game can be completed or failed in a handful of different ways or simply skipped and moved on to other ones. And also, the game's combat system is turn based, meaning you can take time and think wether to aim your gun at the mob's left leg or open your backpack and reload your gun, take a stimpack instead. The environment - post-apocalyptic desert, towns built with junk and underground vaults - you can't say it's the same as every other RPG. Show me a similiar game please. Now I suggest you look a moron up in the mirror, point at him and laugh until you choke. Or alternatively, rethink your arguments.
